summary: This document is an email chain from November 14, 2019, discussing New York Times reporting on a proposed victims' compensation fund by Jeffrey Epstein's estate and the filing of new civil lawsuits against the estate. It details legal resistance to the fund, identifies key lawyers and estate executors, and references ongoing investigations into Epstein's associates.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Deceased financier and accused sex trafficker
persons.context: The central figure whose estate is the subject of proposed compensation funds and multiple civil lawsuits for sexual abuse. He died by suicide in August 2019 while facing federal charges.

persons.name: Kenneth R. Feinberg
persons.context: Retained by Epstein's estate to set up a claims resolution program for accusers.

persons.name: Camille Biros
persons.context: Tapped to help set up the claims resolution program; previously worked on restitution for Catholic Church abuse victims.

persons.name: Jordana Feldman
persons.context: Tapped to help set up and administer the claims resolution program; previously oversaw the September 11 Victims Compensation Fund.

persons.name: Bradley Edwards
persons.context: Filed a court document stating his client does not believe alternative dispute resolution should stay litigation against the estate.

persons.name: Roberta Kaplan
persons.context: Objected to the estate's compensation fund plan, calling it 'astonishing' and a 'continuation of his crimes and abuse after his death.'

persons.name: David Brodie
persons.context: Expressed cautious optimism about a resolution program but raised concerns about the process potentially exacerbating victimization.

persons.name: Bennet Moskowitz
persons.context: Hired to handle lawsuits by accusers; did not respond to requests for comment on the proposed fund.

persons.name: Darren Indyke
persons.role: Executor of Epstein's estate, longtime lawyer for Epstein
persons.context: Named as an executor of Epstein's estate and a defendant in civil lawsuits. He was Epstein's longtime New York lawyer.

persons.name: Richard Kahn
persons.role: Executor of Epstein's estate, accountant for Epstein's companies
persons.context: Named as an executor of Epstein's estate and a defendant in civil lawsuits. He was an accountant for some of Epstein's companies.

persons.name: David Boies
persons.context: Filed lawsuits on behalf of at least three accusers against Epstein's estate. Previously represented an accuser in a defamation case against Alan Dershowitz.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Accused of procuring young women and underage girls for Epstein and participating in the abuse. Named in civil lawsuits.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.context: Mentioned as visiting Epstein's mansion. He is in a legal feud with Boies Schiller Flexner and has forcefully denied allegations of sexual misconduct.

persons.name: Joshua Schiller
persons.context: Representing Epstein accusers in litigation against the estate.

persons.name: Sigrid McCawley
persons.context: Representing Epstein accusers in litigation against the estate.

persons.name: Matthew Goldstein
persons.context: Author of the New York Times article about the possible victims fund, dated November 13, 2019.

persons.name: Tom McParland
persons.context: Author of the article 'Boies Schiller Sues Jeffrey Epstein Estate on Behalf of 3 Sexual Abuse Accusers', dated November 12, 2019.

events.title: Boies Schiller files lawsuits against Epstein estate
events.description: Boies Schiller Flexner attorneys file at least three lawsuits in U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York on behalf of women alleging sexual abuse by Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: NYT reports on possible Epstein victims fund
events.description: The New York Times reports that lawyers for Jeffrey Epstein's estate are considering a 'claims resolution program' to pay accusers, with Kenneth Feinberg retained to set it up.

events.title: Federal indictment against Epstein dismissed
events.description: Federal prosecutors dismiss the sex-trafficking indictment against Jeffrey Epstein following his suicide, starting a one-year clock for crime victims to file civil lawsuits in New York.

events.title: Epstein's death by suicide
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein kills himself in August while facing federal sex trafficking charges at the Manhattan Correctional Center.

events.title: Epstein's Florida plea deal
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pleads guilty in Florida state court to soliciting prostitution from a minor. Court filings estimated he had sexual activity with at least 30 underage girls.

events.title: SDNY meets with Epstein accusers
events.description: Representatives from the U.S. Attorney's Office in Manhattan meet with some of Epstein's accusers and their lawyers to discuss the ongoing investigation into potential accomplices.

locations: U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York
keyFacts: Epstein's estate, valued at about $577 million, proposed a 'claims resolution program' overseen by Kenneth Feinberg to compensate accusers, but faced immediate resistance from some victims' lawyers.
Three new civil lawsuits were filed against Epstein's estate in November 2019, with allegations detailing abuse occurring between 1995 and 2002 and implicating Ghislaine Maxwell.
The executors of Epstein's estate are his longtime lawyer, Darren Indyke, and his accountant, Richard Kahn, who are named as defendants in the civil suits.
Federal prosecutors dismissed the criminal case against Epstein on August 29, 2019, after his suicide, triggering a one-year window for victims to file civil claims under New York law.

The U.S. Attorney's Office in Manhattan informed accusers they were investigating potential charges against people who may have helped Epstein, indicating the criminal probe was continuing beyond his death.
